snippet: The United Nations top official for emergency operations said the cease-fire in Homs — the only achievement from peace talks — cannot be considered “progress,” and aid workers should be able to do their work without getting shot.
abstract: Valerie Amos, top United Nations official for emergency operations, says cease-fire in Homs, only achievement from Syrian peace talks, cannot in itself be considered progress, and aid workers should be able to do their work without getting shot; Amos stops short of calling for enforcement measures.

byline.original: By SOMINI SENGUPTA and ANNE BARNARD
byline.contributor: Somini Sengupta reported from the United Nations, and Anne Barnard from Geneva. Nick Cumming-Bruce contributed reporting from Geneva.

lead_paragraph: The United Nations top official for emergency operations said the cease-fire in Homs — the only achievement from peace talks — cannot be considered “progress,” and aid workers should be able to do their work without getting shot.

headline.main: U.N. Security Council Urged to Act on Humanitarian Aid to Syria
headline.print_headline: Security Council Urged to Act on Syria Policy

keywords.value: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
